title: Colour Grading For BEGINNERS (DaVinci Resolve Tutorial)
relevance: DaVinci Resolve Color Page tutorial directly applicable to our post-production workflow. Teaches node chain structure (WB->EXP->SAT), PowerGrades for brand consistency, and color matching techniques critical for unifying Dzine-generated images and Ray avatar segments.
summary: Comprehensive beginner DaVinci Resolve Color Page tutorial covering project setup (YRGB, Rec.709-A), node chains, Primaries (Color Wheels + Log Wheels), Hue vs Hue curves, Color Warper, AI Cinematic Haze, Stills Gallery, PowerGrades, and CST nodes. Screen recording with circular webcam overlay, five diverse B-roll clips as examples. 284K views in ~7 months.

key_insights.insight: Node chain WB -> EXP -> SAT is the foundational structure for every grade — should be our default Resolve project template
PowerGrades enable reusable grade presets — create a 'Rayviews Standard' PowerGrade and apply to every video for brand consistency
Log Wheels (Shadow/Midtone/Highlights) give per-range control ideal for matching Dzine images and Ray avatar exposure into a cohesive look
Hue vs Hue curves allow selective hue correction — critical for fixing per-product color drift from Dzine generation without affecting other colors
Project color management: DaVinci YRGB color science with Rec.709-A timeline/output color space is standard for YouTube delivery
AI Cinematic Haze (Depth Map + Near Limit + Atmospheric Scattering) adds subtle depth to flat Dzine-generated product images
CST (Color Space Transform) node handles input color space conversion when mixing sRGB (Dzine), webcam, and other sources
Scopes (Vectorscope, Waveform, Parade) provide objective measurement for consistent exposure and color across all clips — use as QA check before export
Color Warper (Chroma Warp) enables advanced chroma manipulation for fine-tuning product image saturation and hue in specific color regions
Stills Gallery allows saving and comparing reference grades across clips — useful for matching product segments to each other

editing_style.transitions: hard cuts between Resolve panels and B-roll clips
editing_style.text_overlays: minimal — relies on Resolve UI as visual reference
editing_style.graphics: circular webcam overlay (top-right, teal/green border) — no animated graphics
editing_style.pacing: steady tutorial pace — ~2 minutes per concept, 10 major topics in 20 minutes
editing_style.camera_work: screen recording with fixed circular webcam overlay, occasional full-screen presenter
editing_style.product_presentation: five diverse cinematic B-roll clips as color grading examples (torii gate, beach, night city, greenhouse, desert)
editing_style.structure: hook → project setup → node chain → color wheels → log wheels → hue vs hue → color warper → AI haze → stills/PowerGrades → windows/CST → closing

production_budget_estimate.note: This is a workflow/tools study — no direct asset production. Investment is time: ~30 min for initial PowerGrade creation, ~5-10 min per video for adjustments

action_items.action: Create DaVinci Resolve project template with DaVinci YRGB color science, Rec.709-A output, and default node chain (CST -> WB -> EXP -> SAT)
Grade one reference Rayviews video and save as 'Rayviews Standard' PowerGrade for reuse across all future videos
Establish per-video QA check using Vectorscope + Waveform to verify consistent exposure/color before export
Create separate 'Ray Skin Tone' PowerGrade focused on consistent avatar skin rendering across Lip Sync segments
Test AI Cinematic Haze on flat Dzine product images to evaluate depth enhancement at subtle settings

analysis_meta.transcript_note: Description-only metadata — free LUT download and color grading lesson booking links
